Multi-Level Modeling (MLM/HLM)

Source: R/mlm.R
run_mlm.Rd

Fit multilevel (hierarchical linear) models for nested data structures using lme4. Handles random intercepts, random slopes, and crossed random effects. Provides publication-ready output for consumer psychology research.

Usage

run_mlm(formula, data, REML = TRUE, control = NULL, ...)

Arguments

formula

Model formula in lme4 syntax. Use (1 | group) for random intercept, (predictor | group) for random intercept and slope. See lme4::lmer for full syntax.

data

Data frame containing all variables in the formula.

REML

Logical. Use REML (restricted maximum likelihood) estimation? Default is TRUE. Use FALSE for ML when comparing models with different fixed effects.

control

Optional list of control parameters. See lme4::lmerControl for options.

...

Additional arguments passed to lme4::lmer.

Value

Object of class mlm_result (extends lmerMod) with additional elements:

fixed_effects

Tibble of fixed effect estimates with CIs

random_effects

Tibble of random effect variances and SDs

icc

Intraclass correlation coefficient(s)

model_fit

Model fit statistics (AIC, BIC, log-likelihood)

n_groups

Number of groups per grouping factor

n_obs

Total number of observations

interpretation

Publication-ready interpretation text

lmer_fit

Original lmer fit object

Details

This function provides a simplified interface to lme4::lmer() with output formatted for publication in consumer psychology journals. It automatically:

  • Calculates intraclass correlation (ICC)

  • Extracts fixed and random effects

  • Computes confidence intervals

  • Formats results for publication

  • Generates interpretation text

**Random Effects Syntax**:

  • Random intercept: (1 | group)

  • Random slope: (x | group) (includes random intercept)

  • Uncorrelated: (x || group) (no correlation between intercept and slope)

  • Crossed effects: (1 | group1) + (1 | group2)

  • Nested effects: (1 | group1/group2) or (1 | group1:group2)

**Intraclass Correlation (ICC)**: Proportion of total variance due to grouping. Indicates necessity of MLM:

  • ICC < 0.05: Little clustering, OLS may suffice

  • ICC 0.05-0.10: Moderate clustering, MLM recommended

  • ICC > 0.10: Substantial clustering, MLM required

**Model Comparison**:

  • Use REML = TRUE for final models (default)

  • Use REML = FALSE when comparing models with different fixed effects

  • Compare nested models with anova()

  • Use AIC/BIC for non-nested models

References

Bates, D., Machler, M., Bolker, B., & Walker, S. (2015). Fitting linear mixed-effects models using lme4. Journal of Statistical Software, 67(1), 1-48.

Snijders, T. A. B., & Bosker, R. J. (2012). Multilevel analysis: An introduction to basic and advanced multilevel modeling (2nd ed.). Sage.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Random intercept model: Satisfaction nested within stores
model1 <- run_mlm(
  satisfaction ~ price + quality + (1 | store_id),
  data = consumer_data
)
print(model1)

# Random slope model: Price effect varies by store
model2 <- run_mlm(
  satisfaction ~ price + quality + (price | store_id),
  data = consumer_data
)

# Crossed random effects: Consumers and products
model3 <- run_mlm(
  rating ~ brand + price + (1 | consumer_id) + (1 | product_id),
  data = rating_data
)

# Extract results
tidy_mlm(model1)
} # }
